div1.p: Department of State Monrovia Liberia May 16 1879

The Commissioners in the conviction of the justice of Our , and anxious for a settlement of the Question; yeilded.

An adjournment was agreed upon by the Mixed Commissions in of which they met at Sobymah on the 1st of April last. The result of eighteen days deliberation-during which the Commission examined the Title deeds of this government and took oral testimony of witnesses brought forward on the part of this govern ment as well as on behalf of the native Chiefs repduiating our claims to sovereignty-was another disappoint ments-The Liberia Commissions holding
holding that we had proved our title to the territories known as "," ", Rock & Rock" and "Solymah" and H.m. Commissioners averting that no such countries existed.

The Liberian Commissioners submitted that, according to the terms of the Draft Proposals, above, and the Instructions of both the English and Liberian Commissioners, the matter should be referred tot he American Arbitration for his decision.
This your Commissioners refused to do, their in- ability to do more than take the opinion of the American Arbitration, and claiming that such opinion could have no ef fect in settling the Question unless
unless approved oby H.M. government. In the face of their instructions and the Draft Proposals above cited our Commissioners could not agree to this and the Com- mission adjourned.

Unless, My Lord, the Liberian government have utterly failed to undertand the terms of the Draft Proposals, accepted by both governments as the basis for the settlement of this question, I beg most respectfully to insist that there is a manifest on the part of H.M. Commissioners.
I say error because I cannot conceive that, in the face of the very positive instructions eman ating from H.M. government enjoining
enjoining upon the Commissioners strict im partiality they could allow them- selves to be influenced by any other than moper motives.

I am quite aware that there is a very strong effort put forth on the part of British Tradeers in that Neighborhood to render suc cessful the efforts of the Aborigines to repudiate over authority, and while we have abundant reason to believe that the dismemberment, -aye were the extinctions of Liberia would wokin the opinion of these Traders be too great a price at which to secure for themselves the produce of that country, Yet I am sure that there is too high a sense of justice and honor not

not to say magnanimity in H.M. government, as well as those who represent her in official relations, to sympathise with any such selfish feelings. And I cherish the opinion that it is only necessary to call the at- tention of H.M. government to this subject,in order to have the points in dispute referred to the Arbitration.
Your Lordship will pardon me for further trespassing on your kindness, while I call your attention to one or two points.
In this Question of the North Western boundary of the Republic, whcih has for so many years being pending and which has

has caused incalculable loss to this governments H.M. government sets up no claim to the territory and has therefore nothing to lose by the delay of its settlement, but Liberia on the other hand is con- tinually losing in consequence of this dispute. If you will take into consideration the large amount of money that would have accrued to thus govern- ment had we been permitted to enforce our Revenue Laws, as well as the outlays that we have made from time to time first in efforts to suppress the slave trade, and then to enforce order and keep peace among the several tribes of that seating you can readily under- stand
stand our wish for a speedy settlement of the matter.

And furthermore there is a poin t of far graver character to which it is my duty to call your attention. Infer to the general spirit of insubordination and rebellion against the authority of the government which is springing up among the natives in almost every part of this Republic, growing out of this Question.

Exclusive combinations are being formed among the tribes to throw off then allegiance to this government under the im pression that H.M. government will afford the same encourage ment and support that it is

alleged to be giving to the tribes in the disputed territories. This government cannot for a moment entertain the idea that their expectations will be realized, since it has long since been a matter of record that Great Britain acknowledges the claims of Liberia to all territory between the " on the North West and the "founders" on the South East. Nor can I suppose for a moment that Great Britain would allow on the part of her officials or citizens any actions that would tend to undermine our National Fabric. But I simply make this reference to show the effect that the attitude of H.M. government in connection with the North Western boundary is
is producing on the tribes within our domain.

Trusting that your Lordship will take an early opportunity of calling the attention of H.M. govern- ment to the subject of this dispatch, and assuring you of very high con- sideration, I have the honor to be your Lordship's obt. svt. sd G.W. Gibson Secretary of State
